docs.lead_paragraph: DR. HENRY E. JACOBS is a desperate man. He is desperate enough to make a house call to the State Capitol on March 26, dressed in his white lab coat, along with hundreds of his colleagues. He is asking for reforms that may reduce his soaring malpractice insurance rates. The Connecticut State Medical Society is calling the event its ''White Coat Rally,'' the first of various moves that will put doctors in a place they have long struggled to avoid: the spotlight. But now the spotlight has begun to look like just the thing they need.

headline.main: Doctors Plan Rally Over Malpractice Bills

docs.abstract: Article on White Coat Rally, first of various events planned by Connecticut State Medical Society to spotlight efforts to reduce soaring malpractice insurance rates; hundreds of doctors are expected at State Capitol in Hartford (M)
docs.snippet: DR. HENRY E. JACOBS is a desperate man. He is desperate enough to make a house call to the State Capitol on March 26, dressed in his white lab coat, along with hundreds of his colleagues. He is asking for reforms that may reduce his soaring...

docs.lead_paragraph: If you want to step into a true hall of mirrors, try to figure out the issue of medical malpractice insurance that drove thousands of doctors out of their offices and hosipitals and -- as some wags said -- off the golf courses to protest at the State House this month. The doctors' argument seems perfectly reasonable: having to pay tens of thousands of dollars to protect yourself against rapacious trial lawyers is unreasonable. Best to put a limit of $250,000 on pain and suffering claims by unhappy patients, as other states have done.

headline.main: Medical Malpractice Mess Is One Huge Headache

docs.abstract: Iver Peterson On Politics column on muddled debate over medical malpractice in New Jersey; notes that doctors, who picketed at State House, want insurance premiums lowered and jury awards capped while lawyers insist insurance reforms are needed (M)
docs.snippet: If you want to step into a true hall of mirrors, try to figure out the issue of medical malpractice insurance that drove thousands of doctors out of their offices and hosipitals and -- as some wags said -- off the golf courses to protest at the State...

docs.lead_paragraph: ROXANNE QUIMBY was just looking for a little extra income when she teamed up in 1989 with Burt Shavitz, a local beekeeper, and started a kitchen-table production line to bottle honey and make beeswax candles in rural Maine. In 1991, when Ms. Quimby began making beeswax lip balm, sales soared, so she added other personal care products. She called the company Burt's Bees and packaged its ointments and shampoos in distinctive bright yellow tins and bottles. She sold them through a network of natural food stores, and they were even picked up by Bloomingdale's.

headline.main: From Beehive To Kitchen Table To Mass Production

docs.abstract: Burt's Bees, which makes natural personal care products and distributes them through network of natural foods stores, achieved sales of $43.5 million in 2002, up 30 percent from 2001; Roxanne Quimby, co-founder and president, discusses challenge of moving company into mass market without compromising its commitment to pure ingredients, its employees and environment; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the parents of some severely mentally ill children, it can come to this: pleading with emergency-room psychiatrists who have no good answers. Listening grimly as caseworkers explain their lack of options. Appearing tearfully before family court judges as they take what they regard as a last desperate step in pursuit of medical care. What these mothers and fathers are being urged to do is agonizing: give up custody of their children and turn them over to New York State's child welfare agencies so that they can get the mental health care that they otherwise cannot afford or gain access to.

headline.main: Parents of Mentally Ill Children Trade Custody for Care

docs.abstract: Parents of severely mentally ill children in New York State often face agonizing choice of having to give up custody of their children and turn them over to state child welfare agencies so they can get care they need; private insurance does not pay for children who may need year or more of intense treatment, at costs that can exceed $60,000 a year; photos (M)
docs.snippet: For the parents of some severely mentally ill children, it can come to this: pleading with emergency-room psychiatrists who have no good answers. Listening grimly as caseworkers explain their lack of options. Appearing tearfully before family court...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a letter accompanying the budget plan he released last month, Gov. George E. Pataki upheld the importance of jobs and vowed his proposal ''preserves promised tax cuts and avoids job-killing tax increases,'' so that businesses will stay in New York and flourish. But after reading the fine print, some lobbyists, lawmakers and labor and business leaders said they have found a contradiction: the budget is less business friendly than it may first appear.

headline.main: Fees, as Surely as Taxes, Will Rob the State of Jobs, Critics of Pataki Budget Say

docs.abstract: New York State lobbyists, lawmakers and labor and business leaders say Gov George E Pataki's budget plan is less business friendly than it may first appear; while Pataki has avoided calling for across-the-board corporate or income tax increases, he does propose $1.4 billion in new fees and surcharges that would hit insurance and health care industries hard, and affect other businesses like tire sales and nuclear power (M)
docs.snippet: In a letter accompanying the budget plan he released last month, Gov. George E. Pataki upheld the importance of jobs and vowed his proposal ''preserves promised tax cuts and avoids job-killing tax increases,'' so that businesses will stay in New York...

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST Monday afternoon, a 39-year-old woman reclined on an examination table in the office of one of Manhattan's most prominent plastic surgeons. He swabbed alcohol on her cheeks, and gently pumped a syringe filled with a clear mucuslike substance. A droplet rushed to the needle's end and hung there, looking like a National Geographic photograph of a suspended Amazon raindrop. The doctor injected a tiny amount of the goo into the deep wrinkles running from the sides of the patient's nose to the corners of her mouth. A small mound formed under the skin. Then he made more injections, until there was a string of a half-dozen tiny bumps. He massaged the bumps until they flattened out the wrinkle, and presto, in about 10 minutes, with just a hint of redness, the folds of age were restored to the plumpness of youth.

headline.main: Psst: Want to Buy Some Wrinkle Remover?

docs.abstract: Article on Restylane, injectible drug that has not yet been approved by Food and Drug Administration for use in humans but is being used, nonetheless, by plastic surgeons in Manhattan and elsewhere to smooth out face wrinkles; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE latest interest-rate cut by the Bank of England surprised the British stock market, but not pleasantly. The move was widely viewed as a good-will gesture to investors whose confidence had evaporated with share values. But the reaction has generally been ''thanks, but no thanks.'' After a fleeting gain just after the cut was announced at noon on Feb. 6, the benchmark Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell about 2 percent over the rest of the afternoon, and it remains at about that level.

headline.main: Investing; Dreary Winter for British Shares

docs.abstract: Analysts comment on investment opportunities in British shares, which have declined more than any other major market in January, largely because of selling by life insurance companies trying to meet solvency requirements; graph (M)
docs.snippet: THE latest interest-rate cut by the Bank of England surprised the British stock market, but not pleasantly. The move was widely viewed as a good-will gesture to investors whose confidence had evaporated with share values. But the reaction has...

docs.lead_paragraph: ON the Saturday before the Great New Jersey Doctors' Walkout of 2003, a few minutes shy of midnight, a 5-year-old decided that it would be far more interesting to experience the spectacle in person than to merely hear about it on the news. So this 5-year-old began having seizures, something she had never done before. They were scary things to behold, and her parents, naturally, were alarmed. They were also unclear what to do, since they had been reading for days that the impending job action was going to cause an overload in hospital emergency rooms.

headline.main: Striking Doctors, a Sick Child and a New Appreciation

docs.abstract: Neil Genzlinger Jersey column praises care given by emergency room staff to child with seizures as doctors prepared to stage walkout protesting against malpractice insurance; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THREE years ago, Linda McCabe learned that the two brothers who owned the auto glass company where she worked in Islip planned to dissolve the business. Having worked for others throughout her career, including the Long Island Association, where she marketed a health-insurance program for members, Ms. McCabe decided the time was right to go into business for herself. After the glass company closed, she opened a new company in the same location, handling the same work. She named the company American Patriot Glass, and she hired some of her old co-workers. Many customers probably never noticed the difference. Neither did bill collectors and lien holders, Ms. McCabe said, and they were not mollified when she told them she had no business connections to the old owners.
docs.abstract: Article on newly formed US Women's Chamber of Commerce chapter on Long Island, its first affiliate in New York State; founder and chief executive Margot Dorfman and Linda McCabe, one of chapter's first members, comment; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THREE years ago, Linda McCabe learned that the two brothers who owned the auto glass company where she worked in Islip planned to dissolve the business. Having worked for others throughout her career, including the Long Island Association, where she...

docs.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE on the North Fork have long been ambivalent about the Plum Island Animal Disease Center, the high-security Agriculture Department laboratory one and a half miles off Orient Point that is closed to all but its 200 employees and the occasional invited guest. Elected officials and local residents are quick to point out that the island laboratory, now nearly 50 years old, has become a fixture and a source of steady jobs on the front lines of protecting domestic herds worth billions to the national economy. ''Plum Island provides jobs for a lot of people out here and it has been part of the scenery for as long as I can remember,'' said Linton Duell, the owner of the Orient Country Store, who described himself as ''one of those people who feels it is important for our national defense.''
docs.abstract: Article on possible future of Plum Island Animal Disease Center off Long Island's North Fork, where Department of Agriculture has conducted research for past 50 years on some of most virulent and highly infectious animal diseases in world; some North Fork residents and second-home owners worry about accidents and want facility closed; Department of Homeland Security, which will take over Plum Island in June, may transfer animal disease research to laboratory in Ames, Iowa, and use Plum Island for bioterrorism research; photos; map (M)
